text: {{Infobox writer | name = Lorraine Vivian Hansberry | image = | imagesize = | caption = Lorraine Hansberry, 1959. | birth_name = Lorraine Vivian Hansberry | birth_date = | birth_place = Chicago, Illinois, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = New York City, U.S. | occupation = Playwright, writer, stage director | nationality = American | education = University of Wisconsin–Madison The New School | spouse = }} Lorraine Vivian Hansberry (May 19, 1930 – January 12, 1965) was an African-American playwright, essayist, journalist and activist.Lipari, Lisbeth. "Queering the borders: Lorraine Hansberry’s 1957 Letters to The Ladder" Paper presented at the annual meeting of the International Communication Association, Marriott Hotel, San Diego, CA, May 27, 2003 . Online. 2008-06-28. Hansberry was the first black female author to have a play performed on Broadway. Her best known work, the play A Raisin In The Sun. Hansberry died in New York City of pancreatic cancer on January 12, 1965 at the age of 34. Martin Luther King, Jr. and James Baldwin spoke at her funeral on January 15 in New York.Carter, "Commitment amid Complexity" (1980), p. 40. Hansberry was a playwriter of her time, becoming a cultural icon for many African Americans, and her legacy has been passed down through generations.
